citation.article-title: Desulfacinum infernum gen. nov., sp. nov., a thermophilic sulfate-reducing bacterium from a petroleum reservoir.

p.s: Description of Desulfacinum infernum sp. nov.
Desulfacinum infernum (in. fer' num. L. adj. infernum, that which is, or comes from, below, especially the lower world)
Oval cells that are 1.5 by 2.5 to 3 μm.
Gram-negative type of cell wall structure.
The optimum pH is between 7.1 and 7.5.
Salinity range, 0 to 50 g of NaCl per liter.
Optimum growth occurs in the presence of 10 g of NaCl per liter.

Formate, acetate, propionate, butyrate, isobutyrate, valerate, isovalerate, hexanoate, octanoate, decanoate, dodecanoate, hexadecanoate, octadecanoate, lactate, pyruvate, malate, fumarate, succinate, glycerol, ethanol, propanol, butanol, hexanol, and alanine are used as electron donors and carbon sources.
Benzoate, cresol, citrate, glutamate, glucose, sucrose, fructose, dodecane, and hexadecane are not used.
Sulfate, sulfite, and thiosulfate are used as electron acceptors and are reduced to sulfide.
DNA base composition, 64 mol% G+C (as determined by thermal denaturation).
The habitat is a high-temperature, seawater-flooded petroleum reservoir in the British sector of the North Sea.
The type strain is BaG1, which has been deposited in the Australian Collection of Microorganisms, University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia, under accession number ACM 3991.
